title: Introduction
text:
As part of the Vast Challeng 2023, NGO FishEye International, a nonpartisan organization in charge of understanding the social, political, and economic forces that drive the illegal fishing trade, is seeking help from the Visual Analytics communities to help identify such activities through data.





Specifically, they have spent the past several years collecting data, which they hope will help them to form a more comprehensive picture of this evolving threat. In mid-April, FishEye International made several of their datasets available to the public, along with a series of questions surrounding illegal fishing and its broader impacts.
For more information on the VAST Challenge 2023, please visit the official website here.

title: Something’s fishy…
text:
As part of the VAST Challenge, participants may participate in 3 mini-challenges and one grand challenge. For the purpose of this project, the team will take on mini-challenge 3.

Mini-Challenge 3: Detect Anomalies
FishEye International has been given access to an international finance corporation’s database on fishing related companies. In the past, FishEye has determined that companies with anomalous structures are far more likely to be involved in IUU.
This challenge involves helping FishEye develop a new visual analytics approach to better understand fishing business anomalies.
The specific objectives are:








Use visual analytics to identify anomalies in the business groups present in the knowledge graph.



Develop a visual analytics process to find similar businesses and group them, focusing on a business’s most important features.



Measure similarity of businesses that you group in the previous question. Express confidence in your groupings visually.



Based on the developed visualisation, provide evidence for or against the case that anomalous companies are involved in illegal fishing. Which business groups should FishEye investigate further?



Lastly, a reflection will be done to document the following:

What was the most difficult aspect of working with this knowledge graph?
Did the team have the tools and resources you needed to complete the challenge?
What additional resources would have helped us?

title: Proposal
text:
The team at Fisheye International has taken a big first step collecting large amount of data on the fishing industry. The knowledge graphs provided across the mini-challenges were also useful in providing broad insights to the industry. However, the team believes the data has great potential to go beyond just broad industry trends.
Inspired by Prof Kam and his great enthusiasm for the annual VAST Challenge, team four aims to create an interactive R Shiny App that would allow users the flexibility to quickly identify key business types, toggle between them to dig deep, in order to answer questions from Challenge 3 of the VAST Challenge, to identify potential groups involved in illegal fishing activities.

title: Proposal
text:
The team at Fisheye International has taken a big first step collecting large amount of data on the fishing industry. The knowledge graphs provided across the mini-challenges were also useful in providing broad insights to the industry. However, the team believes the data has great potential to go beyond just broad industry trends.
Inspired by Prof Kam and his great enthusiasm for the annual VAST Challenge, team four aims to create an interactive R Shiny App that would allow users the flexibility to quickly identify key business types, toggle between them to dig deep, in order to answer questions from Challenge 3 of the VAST Challenge, to identify potential groups involved in illegal fishing activities.

title: Proposal
text:
2. Scope and Approach

2.1 Scope
After a brief review of the data, a few problems were observed, and the team would do the necessary cleaning subsequently. We would however, like to highlight that for the purpose of our project, we will narrow down the nodes using a two-step process:

Using the variable product_services, we will identify nodes that are directly associated with the fishing industry.
Using these nodes as an anchor, we will identify all nodes that share a relationship with the main anchor nodes. These additional nodes could include companies that are not in the fishing industry, but supply various forms of products or services e.g., sale of automobiles, electronics, to the industry.



2.2 Assumptions and Approach
To address the main objectives of the challenge, our team has broken the task down to 3 main themes to explore:

First, our assumption is that that companies or individuals with higher than normal revenue and dealing with fishery products are of higher “financial” risks.
Second, individuals who are connected to more than 1 coy are of higher “network” risk than those who are merely associated with 1 coy.
Third, certain countries, with more fishery coys and individuals residing in them are of higher country risk as our lit review shows that IUU tends to occur in countries with with less regulations and enforcement on IUU.

These 3 facets; financial risk, network risk and country of association will serve as the 3 main indicators we will look at to identify potential clusters involved in illegal fishing activities.

title: About the team
text:
Hello! We are Jiahui, Kah Boon and Yixin!
